bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 11, 1890

div1.p: Lazear writes that he plans to travel elsewhere in Scotland before eventually heading to London.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 11, 1890
div1.p:
This morning your letter
of June 29, with also the enclosed
letter of Miss Hoover's and papers came
before breakfast. I enjoyed them all
very much.

Although the hardest of the work is
over here, I am still going on
with my dissection and also
doing considerable studying.
Yesterday evening I went up
to Edinburgh Castle and looked
around a little. The most
interesting part of it was not to
be seen at that hour so I will
have to go there again. I mean
the Crown room where they
keep the old regalia of Scotland.
This evening I took a walk
down the Canongate, and looked
at the Old White House Inn mentioned
in one of Scott's novels and built
in sixteen something.

I then walked on past Holyrood
and along a path on Salisbury
Craig which was a favorite
walk of Sir Walter Scott and
where he cam wrote many
of his poems and novels.

I picked a thistle near the
path which I will enclose
to you. The thistle by the way
is a rather uncommon plant
in Scotland.

I am glad to hear that you are
going around some. Keep it up.
I think it will do you good.
You ask me about the scenery here.
I think the scenery along the north
coast of Ireland and up the Clyde
is finer that anything I have seen
elsewhere. I have spoken of it
to several persons here and
some of them consider it finer
than anything in Switzerland.
I am sorry that Charley Orr has given
up his trip.

It would be hard for me to go to
London by way of the Trosachs as
they are in the opposite direction
but I intend to take a little
trip up there some day next week.
I intend to go down to Rostin
with Norris to-morrow afternoon
and on Sunday I will go to
several of the churches and also
take a ride on the Forth,
I will probably go to London
on Friday.

I am just about to start for
Rostin. I will try to have more
to write about in my next letter
